The option can be either Nomatch (the default) or Match. (You need to specify only the first capitalized and highlighted letter; all characters following the first character are ignored, which can be in uppercase or lowercase.)
If you specify Match, the method returns the position of the first character in the receiving buffer that is in reference, or returns 0 if none of the characters are found.
The default for start is 1. Thus, the search starts at the first character of the receiving buffer. You can override this by specifying a different start point, which must be a positive whole number.

The default for length is the length of the buffer from start to the end of the buffer. Thus, the search proceeds to the end of the receiving buffer. You can override this by specifying a different length, which must be a non-negative whole number.

If the receiving string is null, the method returns 0, regardless of the value of the option. Similarly, if start is greater than receiving_buffer~length, the method returns 0. If reference is null, the method returns 0 if you specify Match. Otherwise, the method returns the start value.

example.title: MutableBuffer class — verify method
example.programlisting: .mutablebuffer~new('123')~verify('1234567890') -> 0 .mutablebuffer~new('1Z3')~verify('1234567890') -> 2 .mutablebuffer~new('AB4T')~verify('1234567890') -> 1 .mutablebuffer~new('AB4T')~verify('1234567890','M') -> 3 .mutablebuffer~new('AB4T')~verify('1234567890','N') -> 1 .mutablebuffer~new('1P3Q4')~verify('1234567890', ,3) -> 4 .mutablebuffer~new('123')~verify("",N,2) -> 2 .mutablebuffer~new('ABCDE')~verify("", ,3) -> 3 .mutablebuffer~new('AB3CD5')~verify('1234567890','M',4) -> 6 .mutablebuffer~new('ABCDEF')~verify('ABC',"N",2,3) -> 4 .mutablebuffer~new('ABCDEF')~verify('ADEF',"M",2,3) -> 4

section.title: word
section.para: Returns the nth whitespace-delimited word in the receiving buffer or the null string if the receiving buffer has fewer than n words. The n must be a positive whole number. This method is exactly equivalent to receiving_buffer~subWord(n, 1).

section.title: wordIndex
section.para: Returns the position of the first character in the nth whitespace-delimited word in the receiving buffer. It returns 0 if the receiving buffer has fewer than n words. The n must be a positive whole number.

section.title: wordLength
section.para: Returns the length of the nth whitespace-delimited word in the receiving buffer or 0 if the receiving buffer has fewer than n words. The n must be a positive whole number.

section.title: wordPos
section.para: Returns the word number of the first word of phrase found in the receiving buffer, or 0 if phrase contains no words or if phrase is not found. Multiple whitespace characters between words in either phrase or the receiving buffer are treated as a single blank for the comparison, but, otherwise, the words must match exactly.
By default the search starts at the first word in the receiving buffer. You can override this by specifying start (which must be positive), the word at which the search is to be started.

section.title: words
section.para: Returns the number of whitespace-delimited words in the receiving buffer.

section.title: &added50;MutexSemaphore Class
section.para: A mutex, or mutual exclusion semaphore is a synchronization mechanism which concurrent activities can use to control access to a common resource.
Mutual exclusion is the requirement that one activity, a chain of execution, never enters its critical section at the same time that another concurrent activity enters its own critical section.
An activity acquires the mutex semaphore before entering its critical section, and releases it after the critical section.
See also keyword instructions .

section.title: &added50;new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new MutexSemaphore instance. Initially the mutex semaphore is in the released state.

section.title: &added50;acquire
section.para: Returns &true; if the current activity has already owned or has just acquired the mutex semaphore. Returns &false; if the mutex is owned by a different activity, or a timeout has occurred.

Nested acquires, from an activity already owning the mutex semaphore, are allowed, with each acquire increasing the mutex nesting level by one. An equivalent number of calls to
are needed to make the mutex available again to another activity.
If timeout is specified it must be a instance or a valid Rexx number. If the value is negative or if timeout is omitted, acquire suspends the current activity until it can get ownership of the mutex.
If timeout is zero, acquire immediately returns &true; if the mutex was acquired, or &false; otherwise.
If the timeout period is positive, acquire suspends the current activity for timeout seconds or until the current activity can acquire the mutex, whatever comes first.
If an activity still owns mutex semaphores when it ends, these semaphores will be automatically released by the interpreter.
See also method .

MutexSemaphore class — acquire method examplesacquire method
mutex = .MutexSemaphore~new .Task~new~startWork(mutex, "work 1") .Task~new~startWork(mutex, "work 2") say "work tasks started"
::class Task
::method startWork unguarded expose mutex name use strict arg mutex, name reply self~doWork(1)
::method doWork unguarded expose mutex name use strict arg level -- five levels of nested acquires if level > 5 then return mutex~acquire say name level self~doWork(level + 1)
may output
work tasks started work 2 1 work 2 2 work 2 3 work 2 4 work 2 5 work 1 1 work 1 2 work 1 3 work 1 4 work 1 5

section.title: &added50;release
section.para: Returns &true; if the mutex semaphore had been owned by the current activity, returns &false; otherwise.

A successful release decreases the mutex nesting level. If the nesting level has reached zero, one of the activities, if any, waiting to acquire the mutex gets released and becomes the new owner of the mutex.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;uninit
section.para: This method cleans up the mutex semaphore when it is garbage collected.

note.para: uninit should not be invoked directly except via an uninit method of a subclass of the MutexSemaphore class. Any such subclassed uninit method must forward to the superclass uninit method.

section.title: Orderable Class
section.para: The Orderable class can be inherited by classes which wish to provide each of the comparison operator methods without needing to implement each of the individual methods. The inheriting class need only implement the Comparable method.
The Orderable class is defined as a MIXIN class.

section.title: &changed50;compareTo
section.para: This method compares the receiving object to the object supplied in the other argument.
This is a default implementation which compares two items based on their .
This method returns -1 if the other is larger than the receiving object, 0 if the two objects are equal, and 1 if other is smaller than the receiving object.

note.para: Classes inheriting from Orderable (like builtin classes , , or ) are strongly encouraged to forward to this default implementation for comparison cases not covered by their class-specific compareTo implementation.

section.title: Comparison Methods
section.para: Returns &true; or &false;, the result of performing the specified comparison operation. The receiver object and the argument are the terms compared.
The comparison operators you can use in a message are:

row.entry: = = method of Orderable class method = of Orderable class

entry.para: &true; if the terms are equal

row.entry: \=, ><, <> >< method of Orderable class >< method of Orderable class <> method of Orderable class method \= of Orderable class method >< of Orderable class method <> of Orderable class

entry.para: &true; if the terms are not equal (inverse of =)
Greater than
Less than
Greater than or equal to
Not less than
Less than or equal to
Not greater than

section.para: All strict comparison operations have one of the characters doubled that define the operator. The Orderable strict comparison operators produce the same results as the non-strict comparisons.
The strict comparison operators you can use in a message are:

row.entry: == == method of Orderable class method == of Orderable class

entry.para: &true; if terms are strictly equal
&true; if the terms are NOT strictly equal (inverse of ==)
Strictly greater than
Strictly less than
Strictly greater than or equal to
Strictly NOT less than
Strictly less than or equal to
Strictly NOT greater than

section.title: Pointer Class
section.para: A Pointer instance is a wrapper around a native pointer value. This class is designed primarily for writing methods and functions in native code and can only be created using the native code application programming interfaces. The Pointer class new method will raise an error if invoked.

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: Creating Pointer object instances directly from Rexx code is not supported. The Pointer class new method will raise an error if invoked.

section.title: Comparison Methods
section.para: Returns &true; or &false;, the result of performing a specified comparison operation.
For the Pointer class, the argument object must be a pointer object instance and the wrappered pointer value must be the same.
The comparison operators you can use in a message are:

row.entry: =, == = method of Pointer class == method of Pointer class method = of Pointer class method == of Pointer class

entry.para: &true; if the wrappered pointer values are the same.

row.entry: \=, ><, <>, \== \= method of Pointer class >< method of Pointer class <> method of Pointer class \== method of Pointer class method \= of Pointer class method >< of Pointer class method <> of Pointer class method \== of Pointer class

entry.para: &true; if the wrappered pointer values are not the same.

section.title: isNull
section.para: Returns &true; if the wrappered pointer value is a NULL pointer (0) value. Returns &false; if the pointer value is non-zero.

section.title: &changed50;RegularExpression Class
section.para: This class provides support for regular expressions. A regular expression is a pattern you can use to match strings.

note.para: The RegularExpression class is not a built-in class and is not preloaded. Use ::requires "rxregexp.cls" to activate its functionality.

section.para: Here is a description of the syntax:

entry.para: OR operator between the left and right expression
Matches any single character
Matches the previous expression zero or more times
Matches the previous expression one or more times
"Escape" symbol: use the next character literally
Expression in parentheses (use where needed)
Matches previous expression n times (n > 1)
Set definition: matches any single character out of the defined set.
A "^" right after the opening bracket means that none of the following characters should be matched.
A "-" (if not used with "\") defines a range between the last specified character and the one following "-". If it is the first character in the set definition, it is used literally.

section.para: The following symbolic names (they must start and end with ":") can be used to abbreviate common sets:

entry.para: Characters in the range A-Z and a-z
Characters in the range a-z
Characters in the range A-Z
Characters in the range 0-9
Characters in :digit: and :alpha:
Characters in :digit:, A-F and a-f
Space and tab characters
Characters '09'x to '0d'x and space
Characters '00'x to '1f'x and '7f'x
Characters in the range '20'x to '7e'x
Characters in :print: without space
All :print: characters without space and not in :alnum:

example.title: RegularExpression class
example.programlisting:
::requires "rxregexp.cls"
"(Hi|Hello) World" Matches "Hi World" and "Hello World". "file.???" Matches any file with three characters after "." "file.?{3}" Same as above. "a *b" Matches all strings that begin with "a" and end with "b" and have an arbitrary number of spaces in between both. "a +b" Same as above, but at least one space must be present. "file.[bd]at" Matches "file.bat" and "file.dat". "[A-Za-z]+" Matches any string containing only letters. "[:alpha:]+" Same as above, using symbolic names. "[^0-9]*" Matches any string containing no numbers, including the empty string. "[:digit::lower:]" A single character, either a digit or a lower case character. "This is (very )+nice." Matches all strings with one or more occurrences of "very " between "This is " and "nice.".

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: Instantiates a RegularExpression instance. Use the optional parameter pattern to define a regular expression pattern that will be used to match strings. You can select the type of regular expression matching to be “greedy” by specifying option MAXIMAL, or to be “lazy” by specifying option MINIMAL. Option MAXIMAL is the default.
Both pattern and match type can be changed with the method.

important.para: RegularExpression defines its own init method. Any subclass which also defines its own init method, must forward to its superclass to complete object initialization. For details see .

example.title: RegularExpression class — new method
example.programlisting: re1 = .RegularExpression~new re2 = .RegularExpression~new("Hello?*")

section.title: match
section.para: This method tries to match string to the regular expression set by calls to the or method.

With option MAXIMAL in effect, it will successfully match only if the whole string matches. With option MINIMAL in effect, any successful match will always start at the first character of string, but doesn't necessarily have to cover the full string. Thus a match will always be a leading part of string.
Method match returns 0 for an unsuccessful match and 1 for a successful match.

example.title: RegularExpression class — match method
example.programlisting:
str = "

Paragraph 1

Paragraph 2

" re1 = .RegularExpression~new("

?*

", "MINIMAL") re1~match(str) re2 = .RegularExpression~new("

?*

", "MAXIMAL") re2~match(str) say "re1 (minimal) matched" str~substr(1, re1~position) say "re2 (maximal) matched" str~substr(1, re2~position) ::requires "rxregexp.cls"

section.para: Output:

section.title: parse
section.para: Returns 0 after setting and successfully parsing the regular expression pattern. The new pattern will be used to match strings specified with methods or . Returns an error code otherwise.
The type of regular expression matching can be set to “greedy” by specifying option MAXIMAL, or to “lazy” by specifying option MINIMAL. The default is to use the current matching type.

listitem.para: An unexpected symbol was met during parsing.
An undefined symbolic set name was specified.

example.title: RegularExpression class — parse method
example.programlisting:
patterns = "A [:alpha:]{4} fl?*.", - "?*[l|e]?*e?*[r|g]?*", - "[invalid" texts = "A nice flower.", - "A yellow flower.", - "A blue flag."
re = .RegularExpression~new do pattern over patterns code = re~parse(pattern) if code == 0 then do text over texts say text~left(16) - re~match(text)~?("matches", "doesn't match") "regex" pattern end else say "error" code "parsing pattern" pattern say end
::requires rxregexp.cls

section.para: Output:
section.programlisting:
A nice flower. matches regex A [:alpha:]{4} fl?*. A yellow flower. doesn't match regex A [:alpha:]{4} fl?*. A blue flag. matches regex A [:alpha:]{4} fl?*.
A nice flower. matches regex ?*[l|e]?*e?*[r|g]?* A yellow flower. matches regex ?*[l|e]?*e?*[r|g]?* A blue flag. matches regex ?*[l|e]?*e?*[r|g]?*
error 3 parsing pattern [invalid

example.title: RegularExpression class — parse method
example.programlisting:
nrs = 1, 42, 0, 5436412, "1A", "f43g" re = .RegularExpression~new("[1-9][0-9]*") do nr over nrs say nr "is" re~match(nr)~?("a valid", "an invalid") "number" end say
-- allow hexadecimal numbers and a single 0 re~parse("0|([1-9a-fA-F][:xdigit:]*)") do nr over nrs say nr "is" re~match(nr)~?("a valid", "an invalid") "number" end
::requires rxregexp.cls

section.para: Output:
section.programlisting:
1 is a valid number 42 is a valid number 0 is an invalid number 5436412 is a valid number 1A is an invalid number f43g is an invalid number
1 is a valid number 42 is a valid number 0 is a valid number 5436412 is a valid number 1A is a valid number f43g is an invalid number

section.title: pos
section.para: This method tries to locate the regular expression set by calls to the or method in the given haystack string.
Method pos returns 0 for an unsuccessful match, or the starting position for a successful match. The end position of the match can be retrieved with the method.

example.title: RegularExpression class — haystack method
example.programlisting:
text = "It's the year 2016!" re = .RegularExpression~new("[1-9][0-9]*") begin = re~pos(text) if begin > 0 then do year = text~substr(begin, re~position - begin + 1) say "Found the number" year "in this sentence." end
::requires rxregexp.cls

section.para:
Output:
Found the number 2016 in this sentence.

section.title: position
section.para:
Returns the character position at which the last , , or
method ended.

example.title: RegularExpression class — position method
example.programlisting:
re = .RegularExpression~new re~parse("[abc") -- illegal set definition say re~position -- will be 4
re = .RegularExpression~new("[abc]12") re~match("c12") say re~position -- will be 3
re~match("a13") -- unsuccessful match say re~position -- will be 2 (failure to match)
::requires "rxregexp.cls"

section.title: RexxContext Class
section.para: The RexxContext class gives access to context information about the currently executing Rexx code. Instances of the RexxContext class can only be obtained via the . They cannot be directly created by the user. It is a subclass of the .

section.title: args
section.para: Returns the arguments used to invoke the current context as an array. This is equivalent to using the (1, 'A') built-in function.

section.title: condition
section.para: Returns the current context condition object, or &nil; if the context does not currently have a trapped condition. This is equivalent to using the ('O') built-in function.

section.title: digits
section.para: Returns the current context digits setting. This is equivalent to using the built-in function.

section.title: executable
section.para: Returns the current executable object for the current context. The executable will be either a or a , depending on the type of the active context.

section.title: form
section.para: Returns the current context form setting. This is equivalent to using the built-in function.

section.title: fuzz
section.para: Returns the current context fuzz setting. This is equivalent to using the built-in function.

section.title: line
section.para: Returns the context current execution line. This is equivalent to using the environment symbol.

section.title: name
section.para: Returns the name used to invoke the current context. If the current context is a method, name is the message name used to invoke the method. If the current context is a routine invoked as an external call, name is the name used to call the routine. If the current context is an internal routine call, name is the name of the label used to invoke the call. If the context is the main part of the program, name will be the package name.

section.title: package
section.para: Returns the object associated with the current executable object.

section.title: rs
section.para: Returns the context current return status value. If no host commands have been issued in the current context, &nil; is returned. This is equivalent to using the environment symbol.

section.title: stackFrames
section.para: Returns an Array of objects representing the current call stack. The first item will represent the current Rexx context and subsequent elements are earlier elements in the call stack.

section.title: variables
section.para: Returns a directory object containing all of the variables in the current execution context. The directory keys will be the variable names and the mapped values are the values of the variables. The directory will only contain simple variables and stem variables, but no compound variables. Compound variable values may be accessed by using the stem objects that are returned for the stem variable names.
See also Rexx Utility function .

example.title: RexxContext class — variables method
example.programlisting:
a = 2 b.1 = a c. = .stem~new c.[] = 1 c.["one"] = 11 dir = .Directory~new dir["item"] = "index" array = .Array~of("a", "e", "i")
say "SysDumpVariables:" call SysDumpVariables drop result
say ".context~variables:" variables = .context~variables do name over variables say "Name="name"," "Value='"variables[name]"'" if name~right(1) = ".", variables[name]~isA(.Stem) then do tail over variables[name] say "Name="name||tail"," "Value='"variables[name][tail]"'" end end

section.para: will output SysDumpVariables: Name=C.one, Value='11' Name=DIR, Value='a Directory' Name=B.1, Value='2' Name=ARRAY, Value='an Array' Name=A, Value='2' .context~variables: Name=ARRAY, Value='an Array' Name=B., Value='B.' Name=B.1, Value='2' Name=A, Value='2' Name=DIR, Value='a Directory' Name=C., Value='1' Name=C.one, Value='11'

section.title: &added50;RexxInfo Class
section.para: The RexxInfo class RexxInfo class classRexxInfo class gives access to Rexx language information and other platform-specific information in a single place. Only one instance of the RexxInfo class can be obtained via the , other instances cannot be created or copied.

RexxInfo provides read-only attribute methods to get
the default settings for NUMERIC , , and ,
, , and , the allowed maximum, minimum, and the number of digits of internal whole numbers used e. g. as arguments to built-in functions, as the right-hand operand of the power (**) operator, or as the values of exprr and exprf in a DO or LOOP instruction,
and , the maximum and minimum allowed exponent values of numbers in scientific notation,
the language processor and its sub-components , , and , and supplemental to that, the source code version control system's ,
the language processor's descriptive , its , and release ,
the interpreter's , addressing mode of its , full path, shared/dynamic , and whether the interpreter is a version,
and the platform-specific values for , , , , , and .

section.title: &added50;architecture
section.para: Returns the interpreter's addressing mode, specified as a number in bits.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — architecture method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~architecture -- 32 /* ooRexx 32-bit */ say .RexxInfo~architecture -- 64 /* ooRexx 64-bit */

section.title: &added50;caseSensitiveFiles
section.para: Returns &true; if the file system is case-sensitive. Otherwise returns &false;.
On Unix-like systems where both case-sensitive and case-insensitive file systems may be mounted, this method returns &true; if the file system root "/" is case-sensitive, and otherwise &false;.

See also File class method
which returns the same information.

example.title: RexxInfo class — caseSensitiveFiles method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~caseSensitiveFiles -- 0 /* e. g. Windows */ say .RexxInfo~caseSensitiveFiles -- 1 /* e. g. Unix-like system */

section.title: &added50;date
section.para: Returns the language processor release date as a string in the default format of the .

See also
method and
keyword instruction ,
which both also return this date as the third to fifth token of their result.

example.title: RexxInfo class — date method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~date -- 9 Dec 2016 /* e. g. */

section.title: &added50;debug
section.para: Returns .true if the interpreter is a debug version, .false if it is a release version.

example.title: RexxInfo class — debug method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~debug -- 0 /* release version */, 1 /* debug version */

section.title: &added50;digits
section.para: Returns the language processor default for the NUMERIC DIGITS setting.

See also
Package method ,
RexxContext method , and
built-in function .

example.title: RexxInfo class — digits method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~digits -- 9

section.title: &added50;directorySeparator
section.para: Returns the platform-specific directory separator used by the file system, "\" on Windows, and "/" on Unix-like systems.
See also File method , which provides the same information.

example.title: RexxInfo class — directorySeparator method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~directorySeparator -- "\" /* Windows */ say .RexxInfo~directorySeparator -- "/" /* Unix-like system */

section.title: &added50;endofline
section.para: Returns a platform-specific string representing the characters. It returns '0d 0a'x (carriage-return, line-feed) on Windows, and '0a'x (line-feed) on Unix-like systems.
See also the environment symbol , which provides the same information.

example.title: RexxInfo class — endofline method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~endofline -- '0d 0a'x /* Windows */ say .RexxInfo~endofline -- '0a'x /* Unix-like system */

section.title: &added50;executable
section.para: Returns a new File instance of the full path of the currently executing interpreter.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — executable method examplesexecutable method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~executable -- (Windows e.g.) C:\Program Files\ooRexx\rexx.exe say .RexxInfo~executable -- (Unix-like system e.g.) /usr/local/bin/rexx

section.title: &added50;form
section.para: Returns the language processor default for the NUMERIC FORM setting.

See also
Package method ,
RexxContext method , and
built-in function .

example.title: RexxInfo class — form method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~form -- SCIENTIFIC

section.title: &added50;fuzz
section.para: Returns the language processor default for the NUMERIC FUZZ setting.

See also
Package method ,
RexxContext method , and
built-in function .

example.title: RexxInfo class — fuzz method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~fuzz -- 0

section.title: &added50;internalDigits
section.para: Returns the NUMERIC DIGITS setting that the built-in functions use internally, which is 9 digits, when running in 32-bit addressing mode, and 18 digits, when running in a 64-bit addressing mode.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — internalDigits method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~internalDigits -- 9 /* 32-bit addressing mode */ say .RexxInfo~internalDigits -- 18 /* 64-bit addressing mode */

section.title: &added50;internalMaxNumber
section.para: Returns the maximum allowed value for internal whole numbers used e. g. as arguments to built-in functions, as the right-hand operand of the power (**) operator, or as the values of exprr and exprf in a DO or LOOP instruction.
See also methods and .

example.title: RexxInfo class — internalMaxNumber method examplesinternalMaxNumber method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~internalMaxNumber -- 999999999 /* 32-bit addressing mode */ say .RexxInfo~internalMaxNumber -- 999999999999999999 /* 64-bit addressing mode */

section.title: &added50;internalMinNumber
section.para: Returns the minimum allowed value for internal whole numbers used e. g. as arguments to built-in functions, as the right-hand operand of the power (**) operator, or as the values of exprr, and exprf, in a DO or LOOP instruction.
See also methods and .

example.title: RexxInfo class — internalMinNumber method examplesinternalMinNumber method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~internalMinNumber -- -999999999 /* 32-bit addressing mode */ say .RexxInfo~internalMinNumber -- -999999999999999999 /* 64-bit addressing mode */

section.title: &added50;languageLevel
section.para: Returns the language processor's language level as a decimal number.

See also
method and
keyword instruction ,
which both also return the language level as the second token of their result.

example.title: RexxInfo class — languageLevel method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~languageLevel -- 6.05 /* e. g. ooRexx 5.0.0 */

section.title: &added50;libraryPath
section.para: Returns a new File instance of the path of the shared or dynamic libraries for the currently running Rexx interpreter.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — libraryPath method exampleslibraryPath method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~libraryPath -- (Windows e.g.) C:\Program Files\ooRexx say .RexxInfo~libraryPath -- (Unix-like systems e.g.) /usr/local/lib/

section.title: &added50;majorVersion
section.para: Returns the major version number of the language processor. The major version number is the first part of the language processor .

See also
methods and , and
keyword instruction .

example.title: RexxInfo class — majorVersion method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~majorVersion -- 5 /* e. g. ooRexx 5.0.0 */

section.title: &added50;maxArraySize
section.para: Returns the implementation-defined maximum allocation size allowed for Array and Queue.

example.title: RexxInfo class — maxArraySize method examplesmaxArraySize method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~maxArraySize -- 100000000 /* 32-bit addressing mode */ say .RexxInfo~maxArraySize -- 100000000000000000 /* 64-bit addressing mode */

section.title: &added50;maxExponent
section.para: Returns the maximum allowed exponent value of a number in scientific notation.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — maxExponent method examplesmaxExponent method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~maxExponent -- 999999999

section.title: &added50;maxPathLength
section.para: Returns the maximum allowed file system path length of a fully qualified path including any filename portion.

example.title: RexxInfo class — maxPathLength method examplesmaxPathLength method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~maxPathLength -- 259 /* e. g. on Windows */ say .RexxInfo~maxPathLength -- 4096 /* e. g. on Linux */

section.title: &added50;minExponent
section.para: Returns the minimum allowed exponent value of a number in scientific notation.
See also method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — minExponent method examplesminExponent method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~minExponent -- -999999999

section.title: &added50;modification
section.para: Returns the modification number of the language processor. The modification number is the third part of the language processor string.

See also
methods and , and
keyword instruction .

example.title: RexxInfo class — modification method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~modification -- 0 /* e. g. ooRexx 5.0.0 */

section.title: &added50;name
section.para:
Returns the language processor's descriptive name in the format that is also returned by , which is
an interpreter identification string (that includes and ),
the interpreter and
the interpreter build .
See also methods and , and keyword instruction .

example.title: RexxInfo class — name method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~name -- REXX-ooRexx_5.0.0(MT)_64-bit 6.05 22 Dec 2018 /* e. g. */

section.title: &added50;package
section.para: Returns a Package instance of all Rexx-defined (namespace "REXX") classes.
See .

example.title: RexxInfo class — package method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~package~publicClasses~items - "Rexx-defined public classes" -- 56 Rexx-defined public classes /* e. g. */

section.title: &added50;pathSeparator
section.para: Returns the platform-specific path separator used used for file search paths, ";" on Windows, and ":" on Unix-like systems.
See also File method .

example.title: RexxInfo class — pathSeparator method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~pathSeparator -- ";" (Windows) say .RexxInfo~pathSeparator -- ":" (Unix-like system)

section.title: &added50;platform
section.para: Returns the name of the interpreter operating system as a string, e. g. WindowsNT for a Windows, or LINUX for a Linux system.
See also keyword instruction , which returns the same information as its first token.

example.title: RexxInfo class — platform method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~platform -- WindowsNT say .RexxInfo~platform -- LINUX

section.title: &added50;release
section.para: Returns the release number of the language processor. The release number is the second part of the language processor string.

See also
methods and , and
keyword instruction .

example.title: RexxInfo class — release method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~release -- 0 /* e. g. ooRexx 5.0.0 */

section.title: &added50;revision
section.para: Returns the source code version control system's revision from which this language processor was built. Rexx code should not rely on the format returned.
See also keyword instruction .

example.title: RexxInfo class — revision method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~revision -- 11636 /* e. g. */

section.title: &added50;version
section.para: Returns the version number of the language processor. The version number consists of the , followed by a decimal point, the , followed by another decimal point, and the .

example.title: RexxInfo class — version method
example.programlisting: say .RexxInfo~version -- 5.0.0 /* e. g. */

section.title: RexxQueue Class
section.para: The RexxQueue class provides object-style access to Rexx .

section.title: new
section.para: Returns a new RexxQueue instance associated with the Rexx external data queue named name.

If name is omitted, the SESSION queue is used. If name is specified as &nil; the new RexxQueue instance is associated with a newly created Rexx external data queue with a system-generated name. If name is specified and an external data queue named name exists, it is opened. If such a data queue does not exist, it is created.

example.title: RexxQueue class — new method examplesnew method
example.programlisting: q = .RexxQueue~new q~queue("line") q~push("header") say q~queued q~pull -- 2 header q~delete

section.title: create (Class Method)
section.para: Returns the name of a newly created Rexx external data queue, which will be either name if no external data queue named name already exists, or, a system-generated name if name is omitted or the external data queue name already exists.
See also method .

example.title: RexxQueue class — create method examplescreate method
example.programlisting: -- no MYQUEUE queue exists say .RexxQueue~create("myqueue") -- MYQUEUE -- MYQUEUE queue already exists say .RexxQueue~create("myqueue") -- S0000000000004B48Q000001E1BEE66F20 (e. g.)

section.title: delete (Class Method)
section.para: Returns 0 if the external Rexx named queue named name was successfully deleted. Non-zero results are the error codes from the RexxDeleteQueue() programming interface.

section.title: exists (Class Method)
section.para: Returns &true; if the external data queue name currently exists, otherwise returns &false;.

example.title: RexxQueue class — exists method examplesexists method
example.programlisting: say .RexxQueue~exists("SESSION") -- 1

section.title: open (Class Method)
section.para: Returns 0 if the external Rexx named queue name exists, or, if it doesn't exist, can be successfully created. Non-zero results are the error codes from the RexxOpenQueue() programming interface.

section.title: delete
section.para: Returns 0 if the external Rexx named queue associated with this RexxQueue instance was successfully deleted. Non-zero results are the error codes from the RexxDeleteQueue() programming interface.

Calling the , , , , or
method of a RexxQueue instance with a deleted external data queue will result in an error.

section.title: empty
section.para: Removes all items from the Rexx external queue associated with this RexxQueue instance. Returns 0 upon success, non-zero results are the error codes from the RexxClearQueue() programming interface.

section.title: get
section.para: Returns the name of the Rexx external queue associated with this instance.

important.para: RexxQueue defines its own init method. Any subclass which also defines its own init method, must forward to its superclass to complete object initialization. For details see .

section.title: lineIn
section.para: Reads a single line from the Rexx external queue. If the queue is empty, lineIn will wait until a line is added to the queue.

section.title: lineOut
section.para: Adds a line to the Rexx external queue in first-in-first-out (FIFO) order. If line is not specified, a null string ("") is added.

section.title: makeArray
section.para: Returns a single-index array with the same number of items as the receiver object. Items in the new array will have the same order as the items in the external queue. The external queue is emptied.

section.title: pull
section.para: Reads a line from the Rexx external queue. If the queue is currently empty, this method will immediately return &nil; without waiting for lines to be added to the queue.

section.title: push
section.para: Adds a line to the Rexx external queue in last-in-last-out (LIFO) order. If line is not specified, a null string ("") is added.

section.title: queue
section.para: Adds a line to the Rexx external queue in first-in-first-out (FIFO) order. If line is not specified, a null string ("") is added.

section.title: queued
section.para: Returns the count of lines currently in the Rexx external queue.

section.title: say
section.para: Adds a line to the Rexx external queue in first-in-first-out (FIFO) order. If line is not specified, a null string ("") is added.

section.title: set
section.para: Switches the Rexx external queue associated with the RexxQueue instance. The new queue must have been previously created. The method return value is the name of current queue being used by the instance.

section.title: &added50;Singleton Class (Metaclass)
section.para: The Singleton class is a metaclass (a subclass of the ooRexx metaclass Class) which can be used for any ooRexx class, if the programmer wishes only a single instance of a class to be created. In this case the class directive needs to denote Singleton in its METACLASS option.
This class is defined as a MXIN class.

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: This metaclass makes sure that only a single instance of a class can be created, a singleton. After a singleton got created each time a NEW message gets sent to the class will cause that singleton to be returned. The metaclass Singleton makes also sure that the singleton object will return itself upon receiving the COPY message by defining a proper COPY method for the singleton.

example.title: Employing the Singleton (meta)class
example.para: The following program defines a class TEST which makes sure that each instance has a unique number in its instance attribute nr. The TESTSINGLETON subclass uses the METACLASS Singleton option to make sure that it only creates a single instance, a singleton. The program will loop over the classes TEST and TESTSINGLETON, creates three instances of each and displays the value of the instance attribute nr and the identityHash value of each instance, which uniquely identifies each each instance of a class (cf. the MAKESTRING definition).

section.para: Output of running the above program (the hash values may differ on each run):
section.programlisting:
creating 3 objects of type: The TEST class round # 1: a TEST[nr=1,identityHash=-49085937] round # 2: a TEST[nr=2,identityHash=-49089489] round # 3: a TEST[nr=3,identityHash=-49093009]
creating 3 objects of type: The TESTSINGLETON class round # 1: a TESTSINGLETON[nr=1,identityHash=-49114993] round # 2: a TESTSINGLETON[nr=1,identityHash=-49114993] round # 3: a TESTSINGLETON[nr=1,identityHash=-49114993]
section.para: As can be seen from the output there are three distinct instances of the class TEST, however the three instances of the class TESTSINGLETON are identical (cf. the values of nr and identityHash).

section.title: StackFrame Class
section.para: The StackFrame class gives access to execution information about an executing Rexx activity. Instances of the StackFrame class can be obtained via the or from a created for a trapped condition. A StackFrame instance represents an instance of an execution unit on the current activity's call stack. It provides information on code location, arguments, etc. that are useful for debugging and problem determination. StackFrame instances cannot be directly created by the user.

section.title: arguments
section.para: Returns the arguments used to invoke the execution frame represented by the StackFrame instance.

section.title: executable
section.para: Returns the executable object for the StackFrame context. The executable will be either a object or a object, depending on the type of the StackFrame element.

section.title: line
section.para: Returns the current line number of the StackFrame context. If the frame instance is not Rexx code (e. g. compiled native code), &nil; is returned.

section.title: makeString
section.para: Returns the frame value as the object's string value.

section.title: name
section.para:
Returns the name associated with the stack frame context. The name meaning depends on the type of context.
If the stack frame context is a method invocation, name is the message name used to invoke the method.
If the stack frame context is a routine invocation, name is the routine.
If the stack frame context is an internal routine invocation, name is the label name used to invoke the internal routine.
If the stack frame context is the initial main part of a Rexx program, name is the name of the file containing the program.
If the stack frame context is an INTERPRET instruction, a zero-length string is returned.

section.title: string
section.para: Returns the frame value as the object's string value.

section.title: target
section.para: Returns the object the method was invoked against, if the StackFrame is METHOD. Returns &nil; for all other StackFrame types.

section.title: traceLine
section.para: Returns the trace back line that would be displayed for error message trace. When possible, this will be the source line of the Rexx code in the call stack. If source is not available, the trace back will identify the method or routine belonging to the stack frame.

section.title: type
section.para:
Returns the type of invocation for this stack frame. Possible values are:
PROGRAM
The stack frame is the top level of a program.
METHOD
The stack frame is a method invocation.
ROUTINE
The stack frame is a routine invocation.
INTERPRET
The stack frame is code created by an INTERPRET instruction.
INTERNALCALL
The stack frame is a subroutine or function call to an internal label.
COMPILE
The stack frame for compiling Rexx code for execution. Many syntax errors will be reported by a COMPILE frame.

StackFrame class — type method examplestype method
interpret "call level2" 21
::routine level2 call level3 31, 32 return
level3: procedure signal on syntax .Method~new("", "~~") return
syntax: do f over condition("o")["STACKFRAMES"] say (f~type f~name"("f~arguments~makeString(, ",")")")~left(27) f~line":" - f~traceLine~strip end
may output
COMPILE () 1: 1 *-* ~~ METHOD NEW(,~~) The NIL object: *-* Compiled method "NEW" with scope "Method". INTERNALCALL LEVEL3(31,32) 9: 9 *-* .Method~new("", "~~") ROUTINE LEVEL2(21) 4: 4 *-* call level3 31, 32 INTERPRET () 1: 1 *-* call level2 21 PROGRAM C:\stackFrame.rex() 1: 1 *-* interpret "call level2" 21

section.title: StreamSupplier Class
section.para: A subclass of the that provides stream lines using supplier semantics. This allows the programmer to iterate over the remaining lines in a stream. A StreamSupplier object provides a snapshot of the stream at the point in time it is created, including the current line read position. In general, the iteration is not affected by later changes to the read and write positioning of the stream. However, forces external to the iteration may change the content of the remaining lines as the iteration progresses.

section.title: available
section.para: Returns &true; if an item is available from the supplier (that is, if the item method would return a value). It returns &false; if the collection is empty or the supplier has already enumerated the entire collection.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the current item in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

section.title: init
section.para: Initializes the object instance.

section.title: item
section.para: Returns the current item in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

section.title: next
section.para: Moves to the next item in the collection. By repeatedly sending next to the supplier (as long as available returns &true;), you can enumerate all items in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

section.title: Supplier Class
section.para: A Supplier object is an iterator that allows the enumeration of an items Collection together with an indexes Collection. All objects inheriting from provide a method, that returns a snapshot of the Collection as a Supplier object, which allows iteration using the instruction. The iteration results are not affected by later changes to the source Collection object.

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new supplier object. The items argument must be an array of objects over which the supplier iterates. The indexes argument is an array of index values with a one-to-one correspondence to the objects contained in the items array. The created supplier iterates over the arrays, returning elements of the values array in response to items messages, and elements of the indexes array in response to index messages. The supplier iterates for the number of items contained in the values array, returning &nil; for any nonexistent items in either array.

section.title: allIndexes
section.para: Returns an array of all index values from the current supplier position to the end of the supplier. Once allIndexes is called, no additional items can be retrieved from the supplier. Calls to available will return &false;.

section.title: allItems
section.para: Returns an array of all items from the current supplier position to the end of the supplier. Once allItems is called, no additional items can be retrieved from the supplier. Calls to available will return &false;.

section.title: available
section.para: Returns &true; if an item is available from the supplier (that is, if the item method would return a value). It returns &false; if the collection is empty or the supplier has already enumerated the entire collection.

section.title: index
section.para: Returns the index of the current item in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

section.title: item
section.para: Returns the current item in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

section.title: next
section.para: Moves to the next item in the collection. By repeatedly sending next to the supplier (as long as available returns &true;), you can enumerate all items in the collection. If no item is available, that is, if available would return &false;, the supplier raises an error.

example.title: Supplier class

section.title: supplier
section.para: Returns the target supplier as a result. This method allows an existing supplier to be passed to methods that expect an object that implements a supplier method as an argument.

section.title: &added50;Ticker Class Ticker class classTicker class
section.para: The Ticker class provides a repeating notification capability by sending a notification message to a notification target each trigger interval.
A Ticker object can be cancelled any time. If cancelled, a cancel notification message will be sent to the notification target.

section.title: &added50;attachment attachment methodof Ticker class methodattachment methodof Ticker class
section.para: Returns the object that has been attached to the Ticker instance upon creation. Returns &nil; if no object is attached.
See method .

example.title: Ticker class — attachment method examplesattachment method
example.programlisting:
eachSecond = .Ticker~new(1, .Target~new, "once each second") call SysSleep 1.5 -- will trigger once eachSecond~cancel
::class Target inherit AlarmNotification ::method triggered -- called each interval use arg ticker say ticker~attachment -- displays "once each second"

section.title: &added50;cancel cancel methodof Ticker class methodcancel methodof Ticker class
section.para: Cancels the Ticker represented by the receiver.
See also method .

example.title: Ticker class — cancel method examplescancel method
example.programlisting:
twiceASecond = .Ticker~new(0.5, .Target~new) call SysSleep 0.25 -- too short for Ticker twiceASecond~cancel -- "ticker cancelled"
::class Target inherit AlarmNotification ::method triggered -- called each interval say "ticker triggered" ::method cancel -- called when cancelled say "ticker cancelled"

section.title: &added50;canceled/cancelled canceled/cancelled methodof Ticker class methodcanceled/cancelled methodof Ticker class
section.para: Returns &true; if the ticker has been cancelled. Returns &false; otherwise.
See also method .

example.title: Ticker class — canceled/cancelled method examplescanceled/cancelled method
example.programlisting: tick = .Ticker~new(0.5 ,.message~new(.stdout, "SAY", "I", "knock, knock")) call SysSleep 0.75 -- knock, knock say "Ticker" tick~cancelled~?("cancelled", "not cancelled") -- Ticker not cancelled call SysSleep 0.5 -- knock, knock tick~cancel say "Ticker" tick~cancelled~?("cancelled", "not cancelled") -- Ticker cancelled

section.title: &added50;init init methodof Ticker class methodinit methodof Ticker class
section.para: Sets up a Ticker with a specified interval. After each interval, the Ticker sends a message triggered to the specified notification target.

The target must be an object that implements the . It must inherit from or be a subclass of the AlarmNotification class, or a Message object (as the Message class inherits from AlarmNotification). If target is a Message object, the method of the Message class will respond by simply sending the specified message.

The interval can be a TimeSpan or a String object. If it is
a TimeSpan, it must be of a non-negative length, which specifies the interval time length.
a String, it must be a non-negative number which specifies the interval time length in seconds.
If specified, attachment can be an arbitrary object that will be attached to the Ticker instance, and can later be retrieved in the event handler. See method .
You can use the method at any time to cancel a Ticker. If cancelled, the Ticker sends message cancel to the specified notification target.

The following code uses a Ticker to display progress information during a long-running task.
Ticker class — init method examplesinit method
.Progress~new(0.5)~monitor(.Task~new, "tenSeconds")
-- defines tasks together with their "progress" methods ::class Task
-- long-running task ::method tenSeconds unguarded expose m n n = 1000 do m = 1 to n -- long-running task call SysSleep 0.01 end return
-- returns running value to be displayed as progress ::method "tenSeconds-progress" unguarded expose m n return m"/"n "steps done"
-- runs task while displaying progress text at each interval ::class Progress inherit AlarmNotification
-- set progress interval ::method init unguarded expose interval use strict arg interval = 1
-- starts ticker, runs task, and returns task result -- (requires names of task and progress methods) ::method monitor expose interval object progress use strict arg object, task, progress = (task"-progress") tick = .Ticker~new(interval, self) object~send(task) tick~cancel
-- displays progress text at each ticker interval ::method triggered unguarded expose object progress .stdout~charOut(object~send(progress) '0d'x)

section.title: &added50;interval interval methodof Ticker class methodinterval methodof Ticker class
section.para: Returns a object representing the interval to which the Ticker has been set.
See also method .

example.title: Ticker class — interval method examplesinterval method
example.programlisting: say .Ticker~new(.TimeSpan~fromSeconds(60), - .Message~new(.stdout, "say", "i", - "another minute has passed"))~interval -- 00:01:00.000000

section.title: TimeSpan Class
section.para: A TimeSpan object represents a time interval with microsecond resolution. The interval may be positive or negative, with a maximum duration of 3652059 days less one microsecond (which approximately equals 9999 years less one microsecond). A TimeSpan object has methods to allow retrieving components like days or seconds, adding to components, as well as allowing arithmetic operations between TimeSpan objects.

section.title: fromDays (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a number of days. The days argument must be a valid Rexx number.

section.title: fromHours (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a number of hours. The hours argument must be a valid Rexx number.

section.title: fromMinutes (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a number of minutes. The minutes argument must be a valid Rexx number.

section.title: fromSeconds (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a number of seconds. The seconds argument must be a valid Rexx number.

section.title: fromMicroseconds (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a number of microseconds. The microseconds argument must be a valid Rexx number.

section.title: fromNormalTime (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a string returned by the Normal option of the built-in function (hh:mm:ss). The TimeSpan will contain an interval equal to the time of day represented by the string.

section.title: fromCivilTime (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a string returned by the Civil option of the built-in function (hh:mmxx). The TimeSpan will contain an interval equal to the time of day represented by the string.

section.title: fromLongTime (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a string returned by the Long option of the built-in function (hh:mm:ss.uuuuuu). The TimeSpan will contain an interval equal to the time of day represented by the string.

section.title: fromStringFormat (Class Method)
section.para: Creates a TimeSpan object from a string in the format returned by the TimeSpan method.

section.title: init
section.para: Initializes a new TimeSpan instance. If the single fulldate argument is used, the TimeSpan argument is initialized to the time span fulldate microseconds. Otherwise, the TimeSpan instance is initialized to either the hours, minutes, and seconds or the days, hours, minutes, seconds, and microseconds components. Each of these components must be a valid whole number within the acceptable range for the given component. For example, hours must be in the range 0-23, while minutes must be in the range 0-59.

section.title: Arithmetic Methods

note.title: Note
note.para: The syntax diagram above is for the non-prefix operators. For the prefix operators, omit the parentheses and argument.

section.para: Returns the result of performing the specified arithmetic operation on the receiver TimeSpan object. Depending on the operation, the argument be either a TimeSpan object, a DateTime object, or a number. See the description of the individual operations for details. The arithmetic_operator can be:

entry.para: Addition. If argument is a DateTime object, the TimeSpan is added to the DateTime object, returning a new DateTime instance. Neither the receiver TimeSpan or the argument DateTime object is altered by this operation. The TimeSpan may be either positive or negative.
If argument is a TimeSpan object, the two TimeSpans are added together, and a new TimeSpan instance is returned. Neither the TimeSpan object is altered by this operation.

Subtraction. The argument must be a TimeSpan object. The argument TimeSpan is subtracted from the receiver TimeSpan and a new TimeSpan instance is returned. Neither the TimeSpan object is altered by this operation.

Multiplication. The argument must be a valid Rexx number. The TimeSpan is multiplied by the argument value, and a new TimeSpan instance is returned. The receiver TimeSpan object is not altered by this operation.

Division. The argument must be a valid Rexx number. The TimeSpan is divided by the argument value, and a new TimeSpan instance is returned. The receiver TimeSpan object is not altered by this operation. The / operator and % produce the same result.

Integer Division. The argument must be a valid Rexx number. The TimeSpan is divided by the argument value, and a new TimeSpan instance is returned. The receiver TimeSpan object is not altered by this operation. The / operator and % produce the same result.

Remainder Division. The argument must be a valid Rexx number. The TimeSpan is divided by the argument value and the division remainder is returned as a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is not altered by this operation.
The TimeSpan is negated, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan is not altered by this operation.
Returns a new instance of the TimeSpan object with the same time value.

section.title: compareTo
section.para: This method returns -1 if the other is larger than the receiving object, 0 if the two objects are equal, and 1 if other is smaller than the receiving object.

section.title: duration
section.para: Returns a new TimeSpan object containing the absolute value of the receiver TimeSpan object.

section.title: days
section.para: Returns the number of whole days in the TimeSpan, as a positive number.

section.title: hours
section.para: Returns the hours component of the TimeSpan, as a positive number.

section.title: minutes
section.para: Returns the minutes component of the TimeSpan, as a positive number.

section.title: seconds
section.para: Returns the seconds component of the TimeSpan, as a positive number.

section.title: &added50;makeString
section.para: Returns the time span formatted as a string in the format -dddddddd.hh:mm:ss.uuuuuu. This is an alias of the method.

section.title: microseconds
section.para: Returns the microseconds component of the TimeSpan, as a positive number.

section.title: totalDays
section.para: Returns the time span expressed as a number of days. The result includes any fractional part and retains the sign of the receiver TimeSpan.

section.title: totalHours
section.para: Returns the time span expressed as a number of hours. The result includes any fractional part and retains the sign of the receiver TimeSpan.

section.title: totalMinutes
section.para: Returns the time span expressed as a number of minutes. The result includes any fractional part and retains the sign of the receiver TimeSpan.

section.title: totalSeconds
section.para: Returns the time span expressed as a number of seconds. The result includes any fractional part and retains the sign of the receiver TimeSpan.

section.title: totalMicroseconds
section.para: Returns the time span expressed as a number of microseconds. The result retains the sign of the receiver TimeSpan.

section.title: hashCode
section.para: Returns a string value that is used as a hash value for MapCollection such as Table, Relation, Set, Bag, and Directory.

section.title: addWeeks
section.para: Adds weeks to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The weeks value must be a valid number, including fractional values. Negative values result in week being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: addDays
section.para: Adds days to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The days value must be a valid number, including fractional values. Negative values result in days being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: addHours
section.para: Adds hours to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The hours value must be a valid number, including fractional values. Negative values result in hours being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: addMinutes
section.para: Adds minutes to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The minutes value must be a valid number, including fractional values. Negative values result in minutes being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: addSeconds
section.para: Adds seconds to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The seconds value must be a valid number, including fractional values. Negative values result in seconds being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: addMicroseconds
section.para: Adds microseconds to the TimeSpan object, returning a new TimeSpan instance. The receiver TimeSpan object is unchanged. The microseconds value must be a valid whole number. Negative values result in microseconds being subtracted from the TimeSpan value.

section.title: sign
section.para: Returns -1 if the TimeSpan duration is negative, 1 if it is positive, and 0 if it is zero.
See also method .

section.title: string
section.para: Returns TimeSpan formatted as a string. The string value is in the format -dddddddd.hh:mm:ss.uuuuuu. If the TimeSpan is positive or zero, the sign is omitted. The days field will be formatted without leading zeros or blanks. If the TimeSpan duration is less than a day, the days field and the period separator will be omitted.

section.title: &added51;TraceObject Class
section.para:
The TraceObject class subclasses
(a ) and uses unique character strings for its indexes. It gets used to store trace related information including execution context information that may be helpful to trace and to () programs.
When TRACE is active (cf. and ) an instance of this class gets created for each traced clause and the traced context information gets filled in (cf. class method).

By default the created TraceObject instance gets sent to the .traceOutput monitor for displaying its string value (the instance will get the makeString message sent and as a result returns a string representing it, cf. and below). The TraceObject class attribute
controls globally how the trace line gets formatted.

The TraceObject class attribute
can be used to collect all created traceObjects and analyze them programmatically at a later time. For further information about debugging multithreaded programs using and this class see .

section.title: &added51;activate (Class Method)
section.para:
This class method initializes the class attributes. It sets the class attribute
to N (normal), the class attribute
to &nil; and the class attribute
to 0.
See also in the .

section.title: &added51;collector (Class Method)
section.para: The collector class attribute controls whether created traceObjects get collected or not. If its value is set to &nil; (default) then traceObjects are not collected.
Returns the current value of the class attribute collector.

section.title: &added51;collector= (Class Method)
section.para: The class attribute collector controls whether created traceObjects get collected or not. If its value is set to &nil; (default) then traceObjects are not collected.

Sets the class attribute collector to the supplied object. If object is not &nil; then from that moment on the
method will send newly created traceObjects using the APPEND message to the collector object.

note.title: Note
note.para:
Any understands the APPEND message such that one can use e.g. the or
for collecting the traceObjects.

section.title: &added51;counter (Class Method)
section.para: This class attribute is used to assign a unique number to each newly created traceObject in the method. Its value represents the total number of traceObjects created so far.
Returns the current value of the class attribute counter, which can be 0 if no instance has been created yet, otherwise the total number of created TraceObject instances.

section.title: &added51;makeStringImpl (Class Method)
section.para: This class method implements the traceline formatting according to the current setting of the class attribute .
This class method requires a single traceObject as its argument and returns a string representing the traceline depending on the value of the class attribute :

entry.para: "normal", returns the entry "TRACELINE"
"thread", the trace line will get formatted with the trace prefix getting the thread number (entry "THREAD") inserted after the second character

"standard", the trace line will get formatted by prepending a bracketed string that indicates the thread and the invocation number, e.g. "[T1 I2 ]" (entries "THREAD" and "INVOCATION") and if a method gets traced in addition whether it was defined guarded or unguarded (entry "ISGUARDED"), u if currently a guarded method is unguarded or g if currently an unguarded method is guarded or blank else, the attribute pool number (entry "ATTRIBUTEPOOL"), the object scope lock count (entry "SCOPELOCKCOUNT") and whether the object scope lock is reserved (indicated by an asterisk, entry "HASSCOPELOCK") and if the method must wait on the guard condition to turn true (indicated by a W, entry "ISWAITING"), e.g. "[T1 I2 Gu A3 L5 *W]".

"full", the trace line will get formatted by prepending a bracketed string that adds the Rexx instance in addition (entry "INTERPRETER"), e.g. "[R1 T2 I3 ]", and if a method gets traced, e.g. "[R1 T2 I3 Gu A4 L5 *W]".

"profiling" ("probing"), no trace line will be shown, yet, each created traceObject will get appended to the class attribute
if not &nil;. This allows post analyzing the execution of traced Rexx programs for many purposes.

section.para: Using one is able to replace this method with a customized method. See also and for an example see .

section.title: &added51;new (Class Method)
section.para:
Creates and returns a new TraceObject instance, adds the trace context information to it and if the class attribute
is not &nil; will send it the APPEND message with the newly created instance as the argument.
The trace infrastructure of ooRexx will create an instance for each trace line and store the following information with the following indexes:

entry.para: a number (identifier), prepends it with the letter A

the caller's object information (created for an invocation entry) stored in a StringTable having the following entries:
"ARGUMENTS" ARGUMENTSCALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
an array of arguments
"EXECUTABLE" EXECUTABLECALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
the routine or method object that gets executed
"LINE" LINECALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
the current line number or &nil; (e.g., if compiled code)
"NAME" NAMECALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
the name associated with the stack frame context
"THREAD" THREADCALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
the thread ID of the caller in case it used a REPLY keyword instruction or a START message to create (spawn) a new thread of execution
"TRACELINE" TRACELINECALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
the traceline of the stack frame
"TYPE" TYPECALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
one of COMPILE, INTERNALCALL, INTERPRET, METHOD, PROGRAM, or ROUTINE
"TARGET" TARGETCALLERSTACKFRAMETraceObject
if executable is a method routine, the object to which the message got sent to, or &nil; else
&true;/&false;, uses an asterisk *, if &true;, a blank character else
a number (identifier), prepends it with the letter R
a number (identifier), prepends it with the letter I
&true;/&false;, uses the letter G, if &true;, the letter U else
&true;/&false;, uses a W, if &true; (object is waiting for guard lock condition to turn &true;), a blank character else (needs TRACE RESULT or TRACE INTERMEDIATES to be in effect)
a sequential number based on the class attribute (used for the default sorting)
the option at creation time, e.g. N or S
the receiver object for which the method runs
a number, prepends it with the letter L

the trace line's object information stored in a StringTable having the following entries:
"ARGUMENTS" ARGUMENTSSTACKFRAMETraceObject
an array of arguments
"EXECUTABLE" EXECUTABLESTACKFRAMETraceObject
the routine or method object that gets executed
"LINE" LINESTACKFRAMETraceObject
the current line number or &nil; (e.g., if compiled code)
"NAME" NAMESTACKFRAMETraceObject
the name associated with the stack frame context
"TRACELINE" TRACELINESTACKFRAMETraceObject
the traceline of the stack frame
"TYPE" TYPESTACKFRAMETraceObject
one of COMPILE, INTERNALCALL, INTERPRET, METHOD, PROGRAM, or ROUTINE
"TARGET" TARGETSTACKFRAMETraceObject
if executable is a method routine, the object to which the message got sent to, or &nil; else
a number (identifier), prepends it with the letter T
the creation

the trace line string used if the class attribute
is set to N (normal)

the traced variable (needs TRACE INTERMEDIATES to be in effect), where further information is available in the StringTable having the following entries:
"NAME" NAMEVARIABLETraceObject
the name of the variable
"VALUE" VALUEVARIABLETraceObject
the value of the variable
"ASSIGNMENT" ASSIGNMENTVARIABLETraceObject
.true if the value got assigned to the variable, .false if the value was retrieved from the variable

section.title: &added51;option (Class Method)
section.para: This class attribute controls how the formatting of the traced line should be carried out. See .
Returns the current value of the class attribute option.

section.title: &added51;option= (Class Method)
section.para: This class attribute controls how the formatting of the traced line should be carried out. See .

This is the setter method for the class attribute option, only the first letter of the option values "Normal", "Thread", "Standard", "Full", and "Profiling" ("Probing") will be saved in uppercase. See .
Allows to set the class attribute option to one of:

entry.para: normal trace line (entry "TRACELINE")
thread will be inserted into trace prefix
standard multithreaded prefix prepended in square brackets to the trace line
full multithreaded prefix prepended in square brackets to the trace line
"profiling" ("probing"), each traceObject will get appended to the class attribute , but ooRexx will not send it to the .traceOutput monitor for displaying its string value.

section.para: For an example see .

section.title: &added51;setMakeString (Class Method)
section.para:
This method allows the Rexx programmer to supply a customized makeString method that will be used to replace . The makeStringMethod argument can be either
a method object, or
a string containing a method source line, or an Array of strings containing individual method source lines (for these cases an equivalent method object is created).
The supplied method receives a single traceObject as an argument and must return a string.
For an example see .

section.title: &added51;unsetMakeString (Class Method)
section.para: Cancels the effect of all previous setMakeString invocations.

section.title: &added51;compareTo attachment methodof TraceObject class methodattachment methodof TraceObject class
section.para: Implements the default sort order using the value of the NUMBER entry which is the creation sequence number.
Returns -1, 0 or 1 This method returns -1 if the otherTraceObject is larger, 0 if the two objects are equal, and 1 if otherTraceObject is smaller than the receiving object (cf. method in the ).

section.title: &added51;makeString makeString methodof TraceObject class methodmakeString methodof TraceObject class
section.para:
This method will invoke the class method
supplying the traceObject pointed to by the self variable as argument and returns its result.

section.title: &added50;Validate Class
section.para: The Validate class provides class methods helping with validating arguments being of correct class, logical or numeric type, or within a numeric range.

section.title: &added50;classType (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that object is an instance of class class.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;length (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is zero or a positive whole number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to .
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;logical (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is either &true; or &false;.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.

section.title: &added50;nonNegativeNumber (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is zero or a positive Rexx number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;nonNegativeWholeNumber (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is zero or a positive whole number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;number (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a valid Rexx number.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;numberRange (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a valid Rexx number in the range min to max, with comparisons done under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;position (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a positive whole number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to .
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;positiveNumber (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a positive Rexx number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;requestClassType (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that object can be converted to an instance of class class by sending it a request message.
If successful, it returns the converted object, otherwise it raises a syntax error for argument name.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;positiveWholeNumber (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a positive whole number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also methods and .

section.title: &added50;wholeNumber (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a whole number under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;wholeNumberRange (Class Method)
section.para: Validates that number is a valid whole number in the range min to max, with comparisons done under NUMERIC DIGITS digits. If digits is not specfied, it defaults to 9.
Raises a syntax error for argument name if the validation fails, else returns with no result.
See also method .

section.title: &added50;VariableReference Class
section.para: A VariableReference instance maintains a reference to another object. It can only be created using a . Calling the new method to create a VariableReference instance is not allowed.

section.title: &added50;name
section.para: Returns the name of the variable referenced.
See also method .

example.title: VariableReference class — name method examplesname method
example.programlisting: variable = 123 say >variable~name -- VARIABLE

section.title: &added50;request
section.para: Forwards to the request method of the referenced variable.

section.title: &added50;unknown
section.para: Forwards to the unknown method of the referenced variable.

section.title: &added50;value (Attribute)

listitem.para: Returns the current value of the referenced variable.
Sets the value of the referenced variable to object.

section.para: See also method .

example.title: VariableReference class — value method examplesvalue method
example.programlisting:
array = 1, 2, 3
say >array~class~id -- VariableReference say >array~value~class~id -- Array
say >array~value~toString(, ", ") -- 1, 2, 3 -- this also works because we have an UNKNOWN method say >array~toString(, ", ") -- 1, 2, 3

section.title: WeakReference Class
section.para: A WeakReference instance maintains a non-pinning reference to another object. A non-pinning reference does not prevent an object from getting garbage collected or having its uninit method run when there are no longer normal references maintained to the object. Once the referenced object is eligible for garbage collection, the reference inside the WeakReference instance will be cleared and the method will return &nil; on all subsequent calls. WeakReferences are useful for maintaining caches of objects without preventing the objects from being reclaimed by the garbage collector when needed.

section.title: new (Class Method)
section.para: Returns a new WeakReference instance containing a reference to object.

section.title: value
section.para: Returns the referenced object. If the object has been garbage collected, &nil; is returned.
